author: dwdsquared2
body:
**Events in the US Today (ET):**

* 09:00am - House Price Index \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:00am - CB Consumer Confidence (May) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * New Home Sales (Apr) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * FOMC Member Quarles Speaks \[2/3 Volatility\]
   * The Senate meets for session
* 12:00pm - The House meets for session.  Lawmakers resume legislative work in the Capitol next month.
* 12:30pm - General White House Press Briefing
* 01:00pm - 2-Y Note Auction \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 01:30pm - COVID-19 White House Press Briefing
* 04:30pm - API Weekly Crude Oil Stock \[2/3 Volatility\]
* Fed officials Brainard, Bostic and Bullard said they wouldn’t be surprised to see bottlenecks and supply shortages push prices up in coming months as the pandemic recedes, but that much of those gains should be temporary.
* CEOs of the largest U.S. banks, including JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs, will testify before lawmakers in the Senate Banking and House Financial Services committees Wednesday.
* The U.S. said Americans should avoid traveling to Japan, with much of the country under a state of emergency over a Covid-19 outbreak that has sown doubts about Tokyo’s plans to host the Olympics in less than two months.
* Biden visited FEMA Monday and said he is doubling the amount of money the government will spend helping communities prepare for extreme weather events while launching a new effort at NASA to collect more sophisticated climate data.
* The White House on Monday indicated that it is “eager” to continue bipartisan talks on a potential infrastructure package despite there being less than a week until the White House’s soft deadline for an agreement and chances of a deal having diminished in recent days. 

**Events in the World Today (ET):**

* 02:00am - Germany GDP (QoQ-Q1) \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 04:00am - Germany Ifo Business Climate Index (May) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Germany Business Expectations (May) \[2/3 Volatility\]
   * Germany Current Assessment (May) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 06:00am - Euro Zone EU Leaders Summit \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 08:30am - Canada Manufacturing Sales (MoM) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:00am - Brazil CAGED Net Payroll Jobs \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 12:00pm - UK MPC Member Tenreyro Speaks \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 06:45pm - New Zealand Trade Balance (MoM&YoY-Apr) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 09:30pm - Australia Construction Work Done (QoQ-Q1) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:00pm - New Zealand RBNZ Interest Rate Decision \[3/3 Volatility\]
* 11:00pm - New Zealand RBNZ Press Conference \[3/3 Volatility\]
* Iran reached an agreement with the United Nations’s International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) on Monday to extend the use of surveillance cameras at Tehran's atomic sites for one additional month. The announcement comes just a day after a high-ranking Iranian politician indicated the use of cameras would not continue. 

**Earnings Before Open:**

* AutoZone, CitiTrends, Cracker Barrel, ViaSat, Dycom

**Earnings After Close:**

* Urban Outfitters, Zscaler, Intuit, Toll Brothers, Nordstrom, ReneSola, Agilent Technologies, Red Robin

[Earnings This Week](https://i.imgur.com/Q5m35tO.png)

author: Suspicious_Ad_CAGR
body:
Your basically saying that "This time is different. the old paradigm doesn't matter anymore. Our society has shifted to much. These businesses transcend normal valuations techniques".

Lots of people will disagree with this approach.

Math is math. High P/E ratios are speculation about future growth potential. Tax software could be a very competitive industry and I can't think of any moats to retain an enduring advantage except the switching costs related to transferring the last years tax information.

Hopefully your right. Maybe not though. I don't know. I've looked into Intuit recently because I used Turbotax. I like the product but Intuit is valued very highly, the revenue is volatile between quarters, I can't see a sustainable competitive advantage. What if Apple releases tax software? My research stopped there.

I'm going to sit this one out.

author: schitaco
body:
$SQ to the moon

Someone discovered a reference to "Square Checking" and "Square Savings" in their recent app update, meaning they're finally launching bank accounts for businesses. 

This means there's basically no point in having a banking relationship for most small merchants, and Square is aggressively coming after midmarket merchants too (restaurants, larger retailers). They'll have access to cheap capital to lend, and have insight into customers' cash flow to make more accurate and timely credit offers than the bank, and get paid directly from receipts. Anyone not named Chase, BofA, Wells, Amex, PayPal, or Intuit is fuk.

Thanks for reading my journal.

author: angelus97
body:
Companies can have any year end they want. AAPLs fiscal year ends Sep 30. PTON is June 30. INTU is July 31. FB is Dec 31. And on and on.

So one company’s Q1 could be another company’s Q3 as an example.

author: IntroductionOne3720
body:
>Turbo Tax thinned out the CPA herd, not the general accounting herd.

So, firstly, this is inaccurate because this is a failure to understand what tax accountants do. 

Tax accountants do not just do tax returns, they also provide tax planning, estate planning, some level of finance management and various other activities. Secondly, [accounting has it's own internal issues](https://www.accountingweb.com/practice/growth/why-cpa-candidate-numbers-have-decreased-part-1) which greatly reduced the number of CPA applications but the number of CPAs or their job growth projection hasn't shifted negatively at all vs. the economy which would be evident if they were being replaced by-and-large.

Secondly, TurboTax, if it provided tax planning services (nevermind that they company Intuit actually hires tax professionals and CPAs to represent their clients) that would actually thin all of accounting specifically in auditing because if properly placed you'd need fewer auditors which actually did happen due to better software and statistical testing methods. There's a lot wrong with this but the largest fundamental element here is that *most people who would require a CPA due to genuinely complex taxes use one*; it turns out that TurboTax isn't thinning anything at all but instead that the general populace simply doesn't have complex returns. [In the U.S. well over a third of taxable income simply went back to those who paid it; the number of people who pay taxes is not particularly high](https://www.statista.com/statistics/242138/percentages-of-us-households-that-pay-no-income-tax-by-income-level/) and if you look over the years ... Yatta yatta.

I don't think anyone actually cares about accountants in general since the whole concept of understanding the complexity of what they genuinely do, especially when talking about tax accountants because not all of them are even CPAs, you can have various types including Registered Agents and CMA designations or CGAs all of whom play a part with, or even can do, taxes if properly designated. This is Reddit but it is hard to just note how deep the rabbit hole goes and realize that most people haven't a fucking clue.

Their entire perspective is the surface of the pond and they think they see the bottom.

author: flobbley
body:
They had run up a LOT since last year and engineering companies this old dont typically grow fast enough to keep up with that kind of growth, I expected their earning to meet or only slightly exceed, at which point i expected overzealous buyers to sell. But they ended up crushing earnings which sent it higher today.

It should be noted that i only pick stocks with a tiny amount of "fun money" so i dont spend a ton of time digging up every bit of information about a stock, usually just check revenue, ratios, and headlines, then intuit the rest. And since I do it for fun I tend to turn over pretty frequently since actually buying and selling is the fun part to me.

In this instance I only owned one share of the company

author: The_Folkhero
body: Don't get me wrong, I own Apple too, in equal weighting in my portfolio. But you hit upon it, % return wise there are better plays. Because isn't it % returns that we are chasing in stocks?! And I am willing, and have, been putting down a larger % on the smaller cap players.. That's why I am not overweight  Apple and am overweight smaller cap companies such as the "baby FAANGs of Adobe, Salesforce, Intuit, and especially, out of FAANG, Facebook (which is not even at a trillion market cap). The Apple trees don't grow to the sky and stock physics apply. And great companies don't always get bigger - just look at the dead money that Microsoft was for a decade. Cisco is another company that was one of the largest stocks back in the day and today it is a relic of what it once was.

author: The_Folkhero
body:
Facebook is the best value in FAAG/MSFT. Lowest market cap = more runway left for appreciation. Best valuation with lowest P/E and P/Cash Flow. Has the most untapped revenue verticals (video, AR/VR, payments, Angie's List type of service referrals, hardware (Portal/Oculus), dating, WhatsApp and Instagram.

Adobe - a "baby FAANG" that has more room to run, market cap-wise, than FAANG. 

Salesforce - same reason as Adobe above, baby FAANG. 

Intuit - under the radar, category killer with tax and accounting software 

Pinterest - scarce social media property that is adding e-commerce functionality with Shopify. 

WISH - WISH's global eCommerce marketplace has an affordable/entertaining mobile shopping experience. Its focus on value conscious consumers, unique array of unbranded product selection from global merchants, and data science driven approach is very sophisticated. In terms of upside, there is potential in local delivery/fulfillment, branded inventory efforts & a subscription revenue stream. The Company is projecting positive EBIT in 2022. A modest 4x P/S multiple at that time should result in a doubling of the stock price from current levels.

Cronos (CRON) - big tobacco's Altria (MO), the largest tobacco company in USA, backs this company with 45% ownership and will likely plug and play its products like a light switch upon federal legalization into its huge point of service network of over 250,000 locations (i.e. convenience stores, etc) is the cannabis company that will likely be the ultimate winner. They are avoiding expensive growing methods by using a creative approach announcing that they will be introducing synthetic cannabinoids for the Canadian market for a 10 cents a gram:

https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/cronos-to-sell-lab-grown-pot-products-in-canada-this-year-ceo-1.1556188

Aside from Cronos, I think the ancillary cannabis companies are the way to play weed stocks because they don't contain cannabis and hence allow listing on the most liquid exchanges such as Nasdaq and institutional money can pour into these cannabis related names now/today as opposed to being shut out of other companies that contain cannabis because institutional money usually has mandates to not allow investing in something that is Federally illegal:

Hydrofarm (HYFM) - IPOed in Dec and a leading hydroponics manufacturer and distributor

GrowGeneration (GRWG) - leading hydroponics retailer

Weedmaps (SSPK) - unique, direct to consumer (DTC), cannabis play on the intersection of tech and cannabis. A type of Uber, Amazon, Yelp and Shopify all rolled into one for cannabis products. A SPAC that will turn into WeedMaps during sometime in the 1st half of this year. This one is special. 

Tim Seymour's cannabis ETF (CNBS) owns a big position in WeedMaps and smaller positions in GrowGeneration and Hydrofarm:

https://www.amplifyetfs.com/cnbs-holdings.html

Twitter (TWTR) - is a unique social media equity that has achieved critical mass. It may have kinks in it in its current state, and yes, I think Dorsey being so egotistical to think he can be a co-CEO of both Square and Twitter is disgusting (as is his beard), but there is a user base there. It might shock people that the political user base only comprises a low teens % component of their total user base with the rest being news, sports and entertainment. Twitter has made some acquisitions recently of Squad and Breaker that really puts them into interesting territory of peer to peer browsing, audio and podcasting - things people should not overlook. 

Coinbase (COIN) - is one of the top 5 most profitable exchanges in the world. Coinbase might make more money than Nasdaq. Coinbase is gonna be huge because this is the first time we are going to be able to directly play crypto in the equity market. Why I like COIN is that it is a play on Bitcoin AND all the other coins out there...whereas bitcoin is just a play on bitcoin, so you are getting all the other coins for free. COIN is heavily (96%) tied to the price of bitcoin, which is very hard to predict. Another advantage of COIN being the first crypto exchange coming onto the market first is that they potentially can use their stock as currency to buy any other competitors. And you don't have to believe in the crypto party line and the dangers of fiat currency and how you need an alternative, because central banks all over the world are printing money like crazy - even if you think this is nonsense, we know that there is a market for this kind of nonsense because gold bugs have been saying the same thing for decades. In other words, crypto has a natural constituency. Like gold, people buy it as a kind of inflation insurance and gold's strength is its scarcity - its supply only increases about 1% per year and it is getting harder and harder to find more - that sounds a lot like Bitcoin to me and I think it is totally legitimate to believe that crypto, in general, can rival gold as a storehold of value.

author: pepesilviafromphilly

author: BigTurboAbarth
body:
I like how you think RKT is only home mortgage. You’re comparing income between JUST Rocket mortgage and JUST UWMC Holdings. RKT owns intuit quickbooks, which is a highly regarded and heavily used business organization system. They also own intuit turbotax, which you’ve probably used to do your own taxes because UWMC sure as fuck didn’t offer that while turbotax has and will continue to be the nations easiest and most popular tax return website.

Ever heard of Rocket home? Rocket auto? Home insurance. Auto insurance. This company has so many avenues for profit, and you want to sit here and blindly call out RKT for being subpar in comparison to UWMC, when you have absolutely no idea how their product/service lineup encapsulates the market in those areas. I’m going to get so many dislikes because nobody here cares about what’s actually good, what’s actually been working, what’s actually been turning profits, etc. Just follow what Joe Shmoe said on WSB, that’ll work out great for you! 

395 shares @ $16.58 cost basis RKT. Because I know what is actually smart to invest in, and I picked the perfect time. Glad you bought in at the top of this company’s P&D. Have fun bag holding when it never goes back up.

author: Dolancorp
body:
Hey guys I sent two checks to the IRS to repay my stimmy.  They cashed both the $1400 and $600 checks within 5 days.  I never even received the $600, intuit is buying FDs with it as we speak.  

This is why I am long $GME.

author: kkInkr
body:
SMH, ADI, AMAT, ASML, ATEYY, AVGO, HIMX, INTT,  KLAC, LRCX, LSCC, MPWR, MU, NXPI, POWI,  PXLW, QCOM, QRVO, SIMO, SWKS, TER,

besides the usual AMD, INTC, NVDA, and TSM. Those 4 imo are outdated.  SMH is the ETF.

Circuitry, CDNS, SNPS, ANSS, they are being ignored, but have dominant roles, imo.
